comments.author: A&N
comments.content: I'm making this tonight. Thank you.

comments.author: amee
comments.content: Yum!!!  garlic and potatoes!!!  (would rosemary work here?)

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Rosemary would work beautifully. I'd be inclined to really finely mince it and add it at the same point as the garlic, but you could also put a couple whole stems in with the potatoes and remove before serving.

comments.author: Erin
comments.content: Potatoes with lots of garlic is the bomb.  Thanks for the recipe!

comments.author: Carolyn Jung
comments.content: Few things are better than creamy potatoes loaded with garlic and herbs. Please pass the bowl this way. ;)

comments.author: Dianna
comments.content: hi this looks great - but what is the purpose of boiling the potatoes before baking till fork tender? thank you!

comments.author: Alessandra
comments.content: Looks good. I often use the chopped parsley/garlic combo, but I didn't know the term Gremolata

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Dianna - good question - the idea is just to get them evenly heated through first, so that the oven time is mainly just about browning them. If you cook small potatoes on that high a temp in the oven, you'll likely have to overdo the outside to get the inside cooked.

comments.author: Ayesha Jameel
comments.content: Your dishes look yum ... loved the presentation of the food ! good work you can view some of my dishes on http://kitchensojourn.blogspot.com ! i would be really happy if you follow it :)

comments.author: UMB
comments.content: Minced garlic in the oven at 500 degrees for 20 minutes (or even five) = nasty burned garlic. I'd advise sauteing the garlic in the oil, then spooning the oil over the potatoes while reserving the garlic, crisping, then topping with the sauteed garlic. After I scraped the burned garlic off my potatoes they were delicious though!

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hmm. I haven't had that problem, as you can see from the picture. But maybe you took the potatoes farther towards crispy than I did, which can be delicious as well - in which case I could see that burning garlic could be an issue. I like the garlic to turn into crisp bits, but not burned, for sure. In any event, thanks for the feedback!

comments.author: RainyDayCottage
comments.content: Like many comments have already said I think garlic and potatoes are an amazing combination and I think I would throw some rosemary in their too. Sounds delicious!

comments.author: Laurel
comments.content: Mmmm, garlic! Potatoes! We're featuring side dishes at the M&T Spotlight and I'd love for you to submit this. http://www.makeandtakes.com/spotlight

comments.author: Marty Krutolow
comments.content:
I can almost taste the crisp in that picture!

Why is it important to mince and not crush the garlic?

Thanks!

Great piece about Dirt Candy btw!
Marty
Marty's Flying Vegan Review
www.martysnycveggiereview.blogspot.com
@veganpilotmarty

comments.author: Michael Natkin
comments.content: Hey Marty - you could crush it if you like, it just might be a little more difficult to distribute, and would likely have a stronger flavor (not a bad thing!).

comments.author: TheNewWoman
comments.content: This is amazing!  I've made these potatoes twice now and both times have resulted in a crispy skin with a smooth center and a lemon and garlic punch.  Thank you so much for sharing.

comments.author: erinwyso
comments.content: You had me at "A whole head of garlic" -- this looks amazing!
